docs.lead_paragraph: The stories of compulsive gamblers could make the hardest heart weep. A 75-year-old man from New Jersey lost nearly his entire retirement fund when he turned to gambling to fight the loneliness and depression that gripped him after his wife died.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on compulsive, pathological gambling, the overlooked addiction; guide to detecting gambling problems (M)
docs.snippet: The stories of compulsive gamblers could make the hardest heart weep.    A 75-year-old man from New Jersey lost nearly his entire retirement fund when he turned to gambling to fight the loneliness and depression that gripped him after his wife died.

docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Is exposure to sunlight the best way to get the amount of Vitamin D that our bodies need? ALISHA BERGER Though there is no question that chronic, excessive exposure to sunlight is harmful to the skin, we should not ignore the important beneficial effect of sunlight exposure -- the production of vitamin D.

headline.main: The Good and Bad Of Sun Exposure

docs.abstract: Pro & Con column on question of whether exposure to sun is best way to get proper amount of Vitamin D; Dr Michael F Holick says it is, while Dr Mark Naylor advises against it; cartoon (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A drug activated by shining light into the eye could offer hope for people suffering from age-related macular degeneration, the leading cause of severe vision loss in the elderly. The condition, a deterioration of the retina, affects an estimated 25 percent of Americans over the age of 65. It is now virtually untreatable.

headline.main: Drug Offers Hope for Elderly With Eye Disease

docs.abstract: Clinical trial suggests that the drug Visudyne could offer hope for people suffering from age-related macular degeneration, leading cause of severe vision loss in elderly; Visudyne, which was developed by QLT Phototherapeutics, is administered intravenously and is activated by shining a laser in the eye so as to minimize harm to healthy cells (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: People with high blood pressure often fail to respond to medication, leading their doctors to prescribe more and more pills for them. Instead, doctors should help them remember to take the pills they already have, according to an international expert in blood pressure control. Speaking in Boston on Friday at a conference on pill-taking behavior sponsored by the American Heart Association, Dr. Hans R. Brunner, a professor of medicine at the University of Lausanne in Switzerland, said that more than half the time, cases of high blood pressure that seemed beyond the control of standard blood pressure drugs could actually be easily controlled when patients began to take the drugs correctly.

headline.main: A Simpler, Cheaper Plan for Fighting High Blood Pressure

docs.abstract: Dr Hans R Brunner, international expert in blood pressure control, urges doctors to help patients remember to take blood pressure medication they already have instead of prescribing more and more pills; reports that in more than half the time, cases of high blood pressure that seemed beyond control of standard blood pressure drugs could actually be easily controlled when patients began to take drugs correctly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: No one had ever said that starting her own allergy practice would be easy, but Dr. Cheryl Lynn Walker was not prepared for the anxieties that beset her after she opened her doors to patients. ''I would get up in the morning, and I would just feel overwhelmed,'' she recalled.

headline.main: Doctors Face the Business of Medicine

docs.abstract: Growing number of doctors ars studying business to help them cope with an environment in which managed care and corporate medicine now rule; feel they need to be as conversant in language of business as they are in healing; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Looking out of the mist-covered window of his fourth floor office at Tufts-New England Medical Center here, Dr. Allen C. Steere inspected the urban sky on a warm spring day not long ago. ''More ticks,'' he warned gravely. ''If you have a mild winter and a warm, wet spring, those are good tick conditions.'' More ticks means more Lyme disease, which Dr. Steere has been studying for 24 years, longer than anyone else. In fact, he was the first to identify the brand new ailment among a baffling cluster of children with swollen knees in Lyme, Conn. And, over the protests of civic leaders, he gave it its name.

headline.main: Lyme Expert Developed Big Picture Of Tiny Tick
headline.kicker: SCIENTIST AT WORK: ALLEN C. STEERE

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Allen C Steere of Tufts School of Medicine, expert on Lyme disease; he gave disease its name and led research effort on Lymerix, preventive Lyme vaccine; has enraged many patients and their doctors by saying that Lyme disease has become a junk-drawer diagnosis, covering maladies from fibromyalgia to hypochondria; photo (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Meals served to young children outside the home may present a greater choking risk than those served at home, according to a report presented last week at a meeting of the American Society of Pediatric Otolaryngology. Dr. James S. Reilly, chairman of the department of surgery at Dupont Hospital for Children in Wilmington, Del., noted that care givers may not always be aware of the most appropriate foods for a given age group. ''Certain foods put children at risk, and it begs us to avoid providing food that younger children can't handle,'' said Dr. Reilly, the lead author of the report.
docs.abstract: Meals served to young children outside the home may present greater choking risk than those served at home, according to report presented at meeting of American Society of Pediatric Otolaryngology (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Most mountain hikers are ending up high and dry, according to a University of Colorado study conducted in Rocky Mountain National Park. At altitudes above 8,000 feet, people need to consume double the water they would at sea level, yet the survey of 126 hikers on a popular 14.5-mile trail elevated over 10,000 feet found that only 1 percent carried a sufficient water load, a half liter per hour of walking, said Dr. Jack Westfall, the lead author of the study. A third of the 126 hikers surveyed carried only one liter for the entire 16-hour trip, he added.

headline.main: For Hikers, the Perils of High and Dry

docs.abstract: University of Colorado researchers find that mountain hikers are not not carrying enough water with them to meet their needs in higher altitudes; at altitudes above 8,000 feet, people need to consume at least double water they would at sea level; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: An experimental drug that normalizes the body's use of insulin appears to be a promising treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome, a common cause of infertility. A study found that the treatment usually restored women's ovulatory cycles while reversing hormonal imbalances and other effects of the condition.

headline.main: Insulin Drug May Treat Ovary Disease

docs.abstract: Experimental drug that normalizes body's use of insulin appears to be a promising treatment for polycystic ovary syndrome, a common cause of infertility; study finds that treatment usually restores women's ovulatory cycles while reversing hormonal imbalances and other effects of condition (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Cyclocross, a sport that combines aspects of mountain biking, steeplechasing and Nascar auto racing, is beginning to develop a following in the United States after decades of popularity in Europe. For the very committed, it is part of the new extreme sports trend, but other enthusiasts hail it as an activity for anyone who can ride a bicycle.

headline.main: In Mud, on Dirt, Over Logs, It's Cyclocross

docs.abstract: Cyclocross, sport that combines aspects of mountain biking, steeplechasing and Nascar auto racing, is beginning to develop a following in United States after decades of popularity in Europe; for the very committed, it is part of the new extreme sports trend, but other enthusiasts hail it as an activity for anyone who can ride a bicycle; cyclocross participants ride laps over narrow loop that is filled with obstacles like logs, sand pits, mud puddles and obstructions that include fences and piles of plywood; photo (M)
